api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title> <jats:p>Summary: TFInfer is a novel open access, standalone tool for genome-wide inference of transcription factor activities from gene expression data. Based on an earlier MATLAB version, the software has now been extended in a number of ways. It has been significantly optimised in terms of performance, and it was given novel functionality, by allowing the user to model both time series and data from multiple independent conditions. With a full documentation and intuitive graphical user interface, together with an in-built data base of yeast and Escherichia coli transcription factors, the software does not require any mathematical or computational expertise to be used effectively.</jats:p> <jats:p>Availability: http://homepages.inf.ed.ac.uk/gsanguin/TFInfer.html</jats:p> <jats:p>Contact: gsanguin@staffmail.ed.ac.uk</jats:p> <jats:p>Supplementary information: Supplementary data are available at Bioinformatics online.</jats:p>

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: TFInfer: a tool for probabilistic inference of transcription factor activities

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: Summary: TFInfer is a novel open access, standalone tool for genome-wide inference of transcription factor activities from gene expression data. Based on an earlier MATLAB version, the software has now been extended in a number of ways. It has been significantly optimised in terms of performance, and it was given novel functionality, by allowing the user to model both time series and data from multiple independent conditions. With a full documentation and intuitive graphical user interface, together with an in-built data base of yeast and Escherichia coli transcription factors, the software does not require any mathematical or computational expertise to be used effectively. © The Author 2010. Published by Oxford University Press. All rights reserved.

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: TFInfer: A tool for probabilistic inference of transcription factor activities

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text: SUMMARY: TFInfer is a novel open access, standalone tool for genome-wide inference of transcription factor activities from gene expression data. Based on an earlier MATLAB version, the software has now been extended in a number of ways. It has been significantly optimised in terms of performance, and it was given novel functionality, by allowing the user to model both time series and data from multiple independent conditions. With a full documentation and intuitive graphical user interface, together with an in-built data base of yeast and Escherichia coli transcription factors, the software does not require any mathematical or computational expertise to be used effectively. AVAILABILITY: http://homepages.inf.ed.ac.uk/gsanguin/TFInfer.html CONTACT: gsanguin@staffmail.ed.ac.uk SUPPLEMENTARY INFORMATION: Supplementary data are available at Bioinformatics online.

api:address.api:line: School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh, 10 Crichton Street, Edinburgh EH8 9AB, UK.

api:field.name: title
api:field.api:text: TFInfer: a tool for probabilistic inference of transcription factor activities.

api:field.name: abstract
api:field.api:text:
Summary

TFInfer is a novel open access, standalone tool for genome-wide inference of transcription factor activities from gene expression data. Based on an earlier MATLAB version, the software has now been extended in a number of ways. It has been significantly optimised in terms of performance, and it was given novel functionality, by allowing the user to model both time series and data from multiple independent conditions. With a full documentation and intuitive graphical user interface, together with an in-built data base of yeast and Escherichia coli transcription factors, the software does not require any mathematical or computational expertise to be used effectively.

Availability

http://homepages.inf.ed.ac.uk/gsanguin/TFInfer.html

Contact

gsanguin@staffmail.ed.ac.uk

Supplementary information

Supplementary data are available at Bioinformatics online.

api:address.api:line: School of Informatics, University of Edinburgh, 10 Crichton Street, Edinburgh EH8 9AB, UK.
